definitions.definition: to use your teeth to cut into or through something
definitions.sensetop: bite into/through somethingbite somebody/somethingbite off something/sth off

examples.text: Come here! I won't bite! *(= you don't need to be afraid)*
She bit into a ripe juicy pear.
She was bitten by the family dog.
He bit off a large chunk of bread/He bit a large chunk of bread off.
The dog had bitten right through its rope.
He bit at his lower lip.

definitions.definition: to wound somebody by making a small hole or mark in their skin

examples.text: We were badly bitten by mosquitoes.

definitions.definition: if a fish bites, it takes food from the end of a fishing line and may get caught

examples.text: The recession is beginning to bite.

definitions.definition: to develop a strong interest in or enthusiasm for something
to start to deal with an unpleasant or difficult situation which cannot be avoided

examples.text: I wasn’t happy with the way my career was going so I decided to bite the bullet and look for another job.

definitions.definition: to fail, or to be defeated or destroyed

examples.text: Thousands of small businesses bite the dust every year.

definitions.definition: to harm somebody who has helped you or supported you
to shout at somebody in an angry way, especially without reason
to stop yourself from saying something or from showing an emotion

examples.text: I bit my lip and forced myself to be calm.

definitions.definition: to try to do too much, or something that is too difficult
to stop yourself from saying something that might upset somebody or cause an argument, although you want to speak

examples.text: I didn't believe her explanation but I bit my tongue.

definitions.definition: alcohol that you drink in order to make you feel better when you have drunk too much alcohol the night before
after an unpleasant experience you are careful to avoid something similar

wordOrigin: Old English bītan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch bijten and German beissen.
